Utils¶

waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.get_obj_name(path: waterbutler.core.path.WaterButlerPath, is_folder: bool = False) → str[source]¶

Get the object name of the file or folder with the given Waterbutler Path.

Quirks:

Object Name is used by the Google Cloud Storage API (both XML and JSON) in the request path, queries and headers to identify the object. Folders’ names always end with a '/' and files’ names never do. In addition, neither of them starts with a '/'.
Parameters:
  • path – the WaterButler path of the object
  • is_folder – the folder flag
Rtype str:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.build_path(obj_name: str, is_folder: bool = False) → str[source]¶

Convert the object name to a path string which can pass WaterButler path validation.

Parameters:
  • obj_name – the object name of the object
  • is_folder – the folder flag
Rtype str:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.validate_path_or_name(path_or_name: str, is_folder: bool = False) → str[source]¶

Validate that path or object name.

Parameters:
  • path_or_name – the path or the object name
  • is_folder – the folder flag
Rtype str:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.build_url(base: str, *segments, **query) → str[source]¶

Build URL with '/' encoded in path segments and queries for Google Cloud API.

Quirk:

Objects’ names in Google Cloud Storage contain '/' which must be encoded. WB calls urllib.parse.quote() with optional argument safe=''. The default is safe='/'.
Parameters:
  • base – the base URL
  • segments – the path segments tuple
  • query – the queries dictionary
Return type:

str
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.decode_and_hexlify_hashes(hash_str: str) → Union[str, NoneType][source]¶

Decode a Base64-encoded string and return a hexlified string.

Quirks:

This helper function inputs and outputs string. However, both base64.b64decode() and binascii.hexlify() operate on bytes. WB must call .encode() and .decode() to convert bytes and string back and forth.
Parameters:hash_str – the Base64-encoded hash string
Rtype str:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.build_canonical_ext_headers_str(headers: dict) → str[source]¶

Build a string for canonical extension headers, which is part of the string to sign.

Quirks:

Google Cloud Storage has very strict rules for building this string. See: https://cloud.goog le.com/storage/docs/access-control/signed-urls#about-canonical-extension-headers

For this very limited version of the Google Cloud provider, only _intra_copy_file uses the canonical extension header and it uses only one. There is no need for extra effort to remove x-goog-encryption-key and x-goog-encryption-key-sha256 or to perform a lexi- cographical sort. TODO [Phase 2]: fully implement this function when needed

Parameters:headers – the canonical extension headers
Rtype str:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.verify_raw_google_hash_header(google_hash: str) → bool[source]¶

Verify the format of the raw value of the “x-goog-hash” header.

Note: For now this method is used for test only.

Parameters:google_hash – the raw value of the “x-goog-hash” header
Rtype bool:
waterbutler.providers.googlecloud.utils.get_multi_dict_from_python_dict(resp_headers_dict: dict) → aiohttp._multidict.MultiDictProxy[source]¶

Construct an aiohttp.CIMultiDict instance from a Python dictionary.

Note: For now, this method is used for test only.

Quirks:

Neither Python dictionary nor JSON supports multi-value key. The response headers returned by aiohttp is of immutable type aiohttp.CIMultiDictProxy while the one returned by aiohttpretty is of aiohttp.CIMultiDict.

WB tests use the aiohttp.MultiDict type for both files and folders during modification and returns the aiohttp.MultiDictProxy type to imitate the behavior of aiohttp.

Parameters:resp_headers_dict – the raw response headers dictionary
Rtype MultiDictProxy:
